channel.title: PI Timer help?
channel.description:
hi guys, how do i make a timer? lol
i mean like a timer i can put inbetween after i pressed a item. so it would like do 3 emotes total after eachother?

item.title: PI Timer help?
item.dc:creator: @Java-RSPS-Noob Java-RSPS-Noob
item.description:
@Java-RSPS-Noob wrote:

[quote=“corpze, post:21, topic:526763”][quote author=Java-RSPS-Noob link=topic=645509.msg4342030#msg4342030 date=1375297765]

Make your client variable final in the parameters and your emote variable final above your event implementation.

Or if you declare emote somewhere else, like at the beginning of the class, it won’t need to be declared as final, but instead public like I originally stated. Usually when you make a variable FINAL it doesn’t change, in this case, the variable emote changes… Thus you don’t want it final and also why I said to declare it ELSEWHERE!

please write it for me i dont understand shit right now
havent slept for loong time
[/quote]then go to sleep, and come back to this topic later!

his post will still be there later. Nobody here is going to spoonfeed you. he has already helped you more than he should had.

but i dont understand wth to do with that line of code[/quote]so because you don’t understand how to do a certain item you lie and say you are tired?

#logic…

Read full topic

item.title: PI Timer help?
item.dc:creator: @iz3_legend iz3 legend
item.description:
@iz3_legend wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:23, topic:526763”][quote author=iz3 legend link=topic=645509.msg4342042#msg4342042 date=1375298738]

Make your client variable final in the parameters and your emote variable final above your event implementation.

Or if you declare emote somewhere else, like at the beginning of the class, it won’t need to be declared as final, but instead public like I originally stated. Usually when you make a variable FINAL it doesn’t change, in this case, the variable emote changes… Thus you don’t want it final and also why I said to declare it ELSEWHERE!

My bad, and your entire method is flawed in general. When multiple people perform the action around the same time the integer you placed at the top of that class outside of the implementation is going to be switching values for all players, not just one. This means the emotes could be performed out of order. Put the variable in the client class and then only declare the client parameter final.
[/quote]
Typically the ints would be placed in player class. Each person would have their own int “emote” then and it’d run from there.

Edit: This is like if you were to use CycleEvent’s for skilling, anyone doing (for instance) flecthing wouldn’t go at the same tick as the previous because they started the CycleEvent first, they would go from when they started the cycle event.[/quote]

You say “Typically” and explain the correct logic after you just told him to put the variable at the head of the wrong class.

Read full topic

item.title: PI Timer help?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“iz3 legend, post:22, topic:526763”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=645509.msg4342026#msg4342026 date=1375297607]

Make your client variable final in the parameters and your emote variable final above your event implementation.

Or if you declare emote somewhere else, like at the beginning of the class, it won’t need to be declared as final, but instead public like I originally stated. Usually when you make a variable FINAL it doesn’t change, in this case, the variable emote changes… Thus you don’t want it final and also why I said to declare it ELSEWHERE!
[/quote]

My bad, and your entire method is flawed in general. When multiple people perform the action around the same time the integer you placed at the top of that class outside of the implementation is going to be switching values for all players, not just one. This means the emotes could be performed out of order. Put the variable in the client class and then only declare the client parameter final.[/quote]
Typically the ints would be placed in player class. Each person would have their own int “emote” then and it’d run from there.

Edit: This is like if you were to use CycleEvent’s for skilling, anyone doing (for instance) flecthing wouldn’t go at the same tick as the previous because they started the CycleEvent first, they would go from when they started the cycle event.

Read full topic

item.title: PI Timer help?
item.dc:creator: @iz3_legend iz3 legend
item.description:
@iz3_legend wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:18, topic:526763”][quote author=iz3 legend link=topic=645509.msg4342021#msg4342021 date=1375297302]
Make your client variable final in the parameters and your emote variable final above your event implementation.
[/quote]
Or if you declare emote somewhere else, like at the beginning of the class, it won’t need to be declared as final, but instead public like I originally stated. Usually when you make a variable FINAL it doesn’t change, in this case, the variable emote changes… Thus you don’t want it final and also why I said to declare it ELSEWHERE![/quote]

My bad, and your entire method is flawed in general. When multiple people perform the action around the same time the integer you placed at the top of that class outside of the implementation is going to be switching values for all players, not just one. This means the emotes could be performed out of order. Put the variable in the client or player class and then only declare the client parameter final.

Read full topic

item.title: PI Timer help?
item.dc:creator: @corpze corpze
item.description:
@corpze wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:10, topic:526763”]Okay if you have cycle events, add something like this (I’m ignoring imports):

Somewhere, declare emote as an int (this all depends on what you’re doing)…

	public int emote = 0;
		CycleEventHandler.getSingleton().addEvent(c, new CycleEvent() {
			@Override
			public void execute(CycleEventContainer container) {
				if(emote == 0){
					c.startAnimation(YOUREMOTEIDHERE!!!);
				}
				if(emote == 1){
					c.startAnimation(SECONDEMOTEID!!!);
				}
				if(emote == 2){
					c.startAnimation(ANDSOON!!!);
				}
				//Now you want to end it too..
				if(emote == 9){
					container.close();
				}
				emote++;
			}
			@Override
			public void stop() {
				emote = 0;
				c.startAnimation(65535);//This is basically a reset anim.
			}
		}, 3);//3 = 3 server ticks = 600 milliseconds x 3 = 1800 milliseconds.

That’s basically it…

Edit: before Java bitches at me, CycleEvents are not easy for everyone to understand, so I made it mostly for him(or her).
The rest is up to you OP.[/quote]

i got this error :

src\server\model\players\packets\ClickItem.java:85: error: illegal start of expr
ession
public int emote = 0;
^
1 error
Tryk på en vilkårlig tast for at fortsætte . . .

and the line i added it to is in :server/model/players/packets/ClickItem

[code]case 10513:

			        public int emote = 0;
            CycleEventHandler.getSingleton().addEvent(c, new CycleEvent() {
                    @Override
                    public void execute(CycleEventContainer container) {
                            if(emote == 0){
                                    c.startAnimation(4069);
                            }
                            if(emote == 1){
                                    cc.gfx0(542);
                            }
                            //Now you want to end it too..
                            emote++;
                    }
                    @Override
                    public void stop() {
                            emote = 0;
                            c.startAnimation(65535);//This is basically a reset anim.
                    }
            }, 3);//3 = 3 server ticks = 600 milliseconds x 3 = 1800 milliseconds.

		break;[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: PI Timer help?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Okay if you have cycle events, add something like this (I’m ignoring imports):

Somewhere, declare emote as an int (this all depends on what you’re doing)…

	public int emote = 0;
		CycleEventHandler.getSingleton().addEvent(c, new CycleEvent() {
			@Override
			public void execute(CycleEventContainer container) {
				if(emote == 0){
					c.startAnimation(YOUREMOTEIDHERE!!!);
				}
				if(emote == 1){
					c.startAnimation(SECONDEMOTEID!!!);
				}
				if(emote == 2){
					c.startAnimation(ANDSOON!!!);
				}
				//Now you want to end it too..
				if(emote == 9){
					container.close();
				}
				emote++;
			}
			@Override
			public void stop() {
				emote = 0;
				c.startAnimation(65535);//This is basically a reset anim.
			}
		}, 3);//3 = 3 server ticks = 600 milliseconds x 3 = 1800 milliseconds.

That’s basically it…

Edit: before Java bitches at me, CycleEvents are not easy for everyone to understand, so I made it mostly for him(or her).
The rest is up to you OP.

Read full topic

item.title: PI Timer help?
item.dc:creator: @50percentelf 50percentelf
item.description:
@50percentelf wrote:

[quote=“Java-RSPS-Noob, post:2, topic:526763”][code=java]

if(blahtimer>blah)
c.startAnimationVariable = blah
c.updateRequired = true;
else if(blahtimer= blah )
c.startAnimationvariable = blah;
c.updateRequired = true;
else if(blahtimer< blah )
c.startAnimationvariable = blah;
c.updateRequired = true;

[/code]

purely assumption lol

inb4 the real programmers say wrong/better way to do it[/quote]

If you were going to do it like this, I’d make the timer == 3 different numbers that way when it’s > or < it doesn’t rapidly repeat an emote.

Read full topic
